item.title: Research Library at NASA’s Goddard Space and Flight Center to Close Friday
item.description: Holdings from the library at the Goddard Space Flight Center, which includes unique documents from the early 20th century to the Soviet space race, will be warehoused or thrown out.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: NASA Goddard
item.media:description: The NASA Goddard Information and Collaboration Center in Greenbelt, Md. The 100,000 volume library will close Friday.

item.title: See the First Iceberg of the Times’s Trip to Antarctica
item.description: For Antarctic veterans and novices alike, the first sighting of an iceberg on an expedition stays “closest to your heart.”
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Cheap Solar Is Transforming Lives and Economies Across Africa
item.description: Chinese panels are now so affordable that businesses and families are snapping them up, slashing their bills and challenging utilities.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Gulshan Khan
item.media:credit: Gulshan Khan for The New York Times

item.title: A Copper Smelter in Miami, Arizona, Faced Tighter Rules. Then Trump Intervened.
item.description: The president exempted a copper smelter in Arizona from air-quality rules. An E.P.A. official guided the company that sought the exemption, emails show.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow and Caitlin O’Hara
item.media:credit: Caitlin O'Hara for The New York Times

item.title: Mamdani Names Top Deputies for Child Care, Operations and Climate
item.description: Zohran Mamdani, the mayor-elect, announced several key appointments who could help implement central promises of his agenda, including universal child care.
item.dc:creator: Troy Closson
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: Emmy Liss, a veteran education leader, will be the director of New York City’s child care office.

item.title: Meet the Ship Taking Us to Antarctica
item.description: Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong gives a tour of the Araon, the South Korean icebreaker that will take him, our photographer and a team of scientists to Antarctica.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Christina Thornell, Kassie Bracken, Leila Medina, Sutton Raphael and Adam Hogan

item.title: Leaving London: Step one in a long commute to the bottom of the Earth.
Raymond’s Biggest Question About the Trip
item.description: Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong sets out on his journey to Antarctica and shares his biggest question for the trip ahead.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Christina Thornell, Kassie Bracken, Jon Miller, Leila Medina and Phil Caller

item.title: Why scientists are studying the Thwaites glacier.
Overlooked Stories
item.description: We look at some of our best stories of 2025 that you might have missed in the year’s avalanche of news.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Evgenia Arbugaeva for The New York Times

item.title: Studying the Melting Continent, if We Can Reach It
item.description: Times journalists are accompanying a group of scientists on an arduous, weekslong trip to study a key glacier in Antarctica. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.media:credit: Jim Yungel/NASA
item.media:description: A calving front of the Antarctic ice sheet observed by a NASA IceBridge mission in 2014.

item.title: Tatiana Schlossberg, Kennedy Daughter Who Wrote of Her Cancer, Dies at 35
item.description: An environmental journalist and child of Caroline Kennedy, she wrote of her struggle with leukemia in The New Yorker in November, drawing worldwide sympathy.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.media:credit: Sonia Moskowitz/Globe Photos via ZUMA
item.media:description: Tatiana Schlossberg in 2019. After learning of her cancer diagnosis, she wrote, “I did not — could not — believe that they were talking about me.”

item.title: Scientists Are Coming to New Conclusions About Antarctica’s Thwaites Glacier
item.description: Recent research has led scientists to new conclusions about the fastest melting glacier in Antarctica. Some are reassuring, others the opposite.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: J. Yungel/NASA
item.media:description: Crevassed ice during a flight over the Thwaites ice shelf in 2012.

item.title: Overlooked Stories
item.description: We look at some of our best stories from 2025 that Times editors thought deserved more attention.
item.dc:creator: Adam B. Kushner
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Twitch streamer Kai Cenat.

item.title: Why This Glacier Worries Scientists the Most
item.description: Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong describes how the fast-melting Thwaites Glacier of Antarctica, is like a cork in a bottle: If it starts to really disintegrate, many more glaciers around it could do the same, with major consequences for sea levels.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Kassie Bracken, Christina Thornell, Jon Miller, Stephanie Swart, Leila Medina, Phil Caller and Nikolay Nikolov

item.title: What Times Reporters Are Taking to Antarctica
What We’re Bringing to Antarctica
item.description: What do a New York Times reporter and photographer pack for a two-month expedition to the fastest-melting glacier in Antarctica? Raymond Zhong and Chang W. Lee compare the must-have gear that they’re bringing for the journey.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Claire Hogan, Christina Thornell, Kassie Bracken, Jon Miller and Leila Medina

item.title: How a Research Trip to Antarctica Deals With Time Zones
item.description: The clocks aboard our icebreaker will be changed several times en route to Antarctica. It’s one of many things that make the expedition feel otherworldly.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: The World Wants More Ube. Philippine Farmers Are Struggling to Keep Up.
item.description: Soaring demand and extreme weather worsened by climate change have wiped out harvests of the popular purple yam.
item.dc:creator: Rambo Talabong and Jes Aznar

item.title: Two Times Journalists Join an Expedition to Antartica
item.description: Our journalists are joining scientists on a research ship sailing to the continent’s fast-melting glaciers.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Raymond Zhong, a Times climate reporter, at Lyttelton Harbour, New Zealand, on Thursday. He’s sailing to Antarctica aboard the research icebreaker Araon.

item.title: She Studied the Health Effects of Wildfires, Until the E.P.A. Cut Her Grant
item.description: Marina Vance had an E.P.A. grant to help homeowners counter the impact of wildfire smoke, until the agency deemed the research “no longer consistent” with its priorities.
item.dc:creator: Interview by Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: Daniel Brenner for The New York Times

item.title: Antarctica bound on a search for clues to Earth’s future.
item.description: As vast, wild and beyond our comprehending as Antarctica may seem, its melting ice could decide the fates of coastal communities for centuries to come
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: On the bridge of the South Korean icebreaker Araon, as it departed Lyttleton Harbor in New Zealand for Antarctica on Saturday.

item.title: Before Electric Vehicles Became Political, There Was the Toyota Prius
item.description: The political polarization of battery-powered cars may have started when Toyota released its first hybrid model 25 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Lawrence Ulrich
item.media:credit: Adam Riding for The New York Times
item.media:description: The marketing for the Toyota Prius may have inadvertently started the culture war around hybrid and electric vehicles by characterizing them as a way to save the planet, some experts say.

item.title: Bound for Antarctica: A Trip to Study the Thwaites Glacier Is Underway
item.description: The continent’s ice is melting and raising sea levels worldwide. Our journalists will be sending regular dispatches as they head there with scientists trying to gauge the dangers.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Mira Rojanasakul
item.media:credit: Ian Strachan/EYOS Expeditions, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A colossal iceberg in the seas off Antarctica in 2024.

item.title: What’s this trip about? Here’s an overview.
Why We Are Going to the Fastest-Melting Glacier
item.description: How much time does the Thwaites Glacier in Antarctica have left? Our reporter Raymond Zhong and our photographer Chang W. Lee are joining scientists and engineers who measure how much sea levels could rise as a result of melting ice.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Christina Thornell, Kassie Bracken, Jon Miller, Thomas Vollkommer, Leila Medina, Stephanie Swart, Nikolay Nikolov and Phil Caller

item.title: Downpours Ease in Southern California, but Flood Risks Remain
item.description: Another wave of rain was hitting the Los Angeles area on Friday, adding to the record-setting precipitation over Christmas.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla and Alexander Nazaryan
item.media:credit: Apu Gomes/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Clouds covered downtown Los Angeles on Wednesday. Rain continued on Thursday and Friday.

item.title: What to pack for a trip to the bottom of the world.
The Race to Save the Sacramento Mountains Checkerspot Butterfly
item.description: The Sacramento Mountains checkerspot butterfly is critically endangered, with the last known larva living in a lab in New Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn and Diana Cervantes
item.media:credit: Diana Cervantes for The New York Times

item.title: Feral Dogs on the Roof of the World
item.description: As many as 25,000 free-ranging dogs roam the cold, high-altitude desert of Ladakh, India. That’s a problem for wildlife and people alike.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Obermann and Emily Anthes

item.title: What We’re Bringing to Antarctica
item.description: What do you pack for a two-month expedition to Antarctica? Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong shows us what he is bringing along for his journey.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Christina Thornell, Kassie Bracken, Christina Shaman, Jon Miller, Leila Medina, Edward Vega, Stephanie Swart and Rebecca Suner

item.title: Tesla Robotaxis Are Big on Wall St. but Lagging on Roads
item.description: Shares of Tesla have hit new highs on optimism about the company’s self-driving taxis. But experts say Tesla is far behind Waymo, which has a big head start.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Ariana Gomez for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Tosses Lifelines to the Struggling Coal Industry
item.description: The Energy Department ordered two coal-burning power plants to remain open, and the Environmental Protection Agency gave utilities more time to tackle toxic coal ash.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Carlos Barria/Reuters
item.media:description: Chris Wright, the energy secretary, ordered that two Indiana coal plants, scheduled to close soon, keep running until early 2026.

item.title: Judge Blocks Conditions Imposed on States Seeking FEMA Grants
item.description: The Trump administration had sought to require states to account for population losses tied to deportations in order to receive emergency preparedness grants.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.media:credit: Carolyn Kaster/Associated Press
item.media:description: Residents searched through debris after a tornado passed through London, Ky., in May. Kentucky is one of 11 states that sued over federal efforts to withhold FEMA grants over population counts.

item.title: Frequently Asked Questions About The New York Times’s Trip to Antarctica
item.description: A Times reporter and photographer are joining scientists on a research expedition by sea to Antarctica.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Mark Baker/Associated Press

item.title: Democratic Governors Are Fighting Trump’s War on Wind Energy
item.description: Leaders in Connecticut, Massachusetts, New York and Rhode Island are racing to save offshore wind farms targeted by the president.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman, Benjamin Oreskes and Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Bob O'Connor for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tower sections for the Vineyard Wind offshore wind farm in New Bedford, Mass., one of five wind projects halted by the Trump administration on Monday.

item.title: Looking Back at a Historic Year of Dismantling Climate Policies
item.description: The Trump administration has aggressively pulled America away from its global role in climate and environmental research, diplomacy, regulation and investment.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump administration has weakened a host of agencies and environmental practices in its first year.

item.title: U.S. Takes a Step Toward Approving Seabed Mining in International Waters
item.description: The federal government said it would hold hearings next month on controversial applications to mine the ocean floor.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ship chartered by the Metals Company in 2021 to assess the potential of seabed mining.

item.title: Trump May Give SpaceX Some Land In A Texas Wildlife Refuge
item.description: In exchange for the land in Texas, the rocket and satellite company would give the government some of its own property nearby, documents show.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: SpaceX’s launchpad near Boca Chica Beach in South Texas.

item.title: In Pursuit of the Monarch’s Magnetic Sense
item.description: The magnetic compass is the last unknown sense in migrating animals. For some scientists, the monarch butterfly is leading the way.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil and Mark Felix
item.media:credit: Mark Felix for The New York Times

item.title: The Pentagon and A.I. Giants Have a Weakness. Both Need China’s Batteries, Badly.
item.description: As warfare is reinvented in Ukraine, and Silicon Valley races to maintain its A.I. lead, China’s battery dominance is raising alarms far beyond the auto industry.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi, Brad Plumer and Harry Stevens
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Trump Administration Loosens Protections for Iconic Greater Sage Grouse
item.description: The government moves to make it easier to drill, mine and graze on 50 million acres of land in the West.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Tom Reichner/Alamy
item.media:description: The greater sage grouse, a large chicken-like bird known for the males’ flamboyant courtship dance, is considered a key indicator of the health of an ecosystem that spans 11 Western states.

item.title: How Blocking Illegal ‘Ghost’ Roads Could Protect Tropical Forests
item.description: New research tries to anticipate road building to identify areas in the Amazon, Asia and Africa that are likely to face deforestation.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.media:credit: Evaristo Sa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A fire in the Amazon in northern Brazil.

item.title: Mercedes to Pay $150 Million Over Claims It Cheated on Emissions Tests
item.description: It’s the latest in a decade-long scandal involving accusations that software “defeat devices” made diesel vehicles seem cleaner than they were.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Charity Rachelle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mercedes-Benz was accused of violating state laws against deceptive trade practices.

item.title: How Trump’s First Year Reshaped U.S. Energy and Climate Policy
item.description: The sweeping changes have affected everything from coal plant retirements to international diplomacy over shipping emissions.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer, Lisa Friedman, Maxine Joselow and Scott Dance
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: An “Unleashing American Energy” executive order signing at the White House in April.

item.title: Trump Halts 5 Wind Farms Off the East Coast
item.description: The Interior Department said the projects posed national security risks, without providing details. The decision imperils billions of dollars of investments.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow and Lisa Friedman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Brian Snyder/Reuters
item.media:description: Parts for the construction of Revolution Wind, one of five projects the Trump administration paused on Monday.

item.title: Washington State Faces Climate Change Reality After Storms
item.description: Two weeks of “atmospheric river” deluges took a toll on business in Leavenworth, Wash., and beyond, reminding the region that a warming planet has brought new uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Anna Griffin and Amy Graff
item.media:credit: Yehyun Kim for The New York Times
item.media:description: Many businesses in Leavenworth, Wash., rely on sales between Thanksgiving and Christmas for 40 percent of their annual revenue.

item.title: Hochul Repeals Rule Allowing New Customers Free Gas Hookups
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul struck down a decades-old provision that raised gas bills for millions of New Yorkers. The move could help curb the use of fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Hilary Howard
item.media:credit: Cindy Schultz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s repeal of a rule that allowed for free gas hookups for some new customers was applauded by climate activists and other supporters.

item.title: Controversial Dakota Pipeline Gets a Big, Belated Government Boost
item.description: A delayed environmental review cleared the Dakota Access Pipeline to continue operating. Separately, a North Dakota judge expressed unusual exasperation over the tangled legal battles.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Thibaud Moritz/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Activists in France earlier this year supporting Greenpeace, which is fighting a verdict against it that could bankrupt its U.S. operations.

item.title: A Somber Mood at Science Meeting as Trump Budget Cuts Continue
item.description: News of the breakup of a leading science institution rippled through an annual gathering of Earth, ocean and space scientists. Many say American science is suffering under the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Mark Makela/Reuters
item.media:description: The National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo., is one of the world’s premier climate and weather science institutions.

item.title: Trump Media Merger With Nuclear Fusion Firm Raises Ethics Questions
item.description: Trump Media plans to merge with a company developing nuclear fusion technology, putting the president’s financial interests in competition with other energy companies over which his administration holds sway.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott and Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s social media company said on Thursday that it had agreed to an all-stock merger with TAE Technologies, a fusion power company.

item.title: Europe Begins to Tiptoe Away From Key Climate Policies
item.description: Europe has some of the world’s most ambitious climate goals, but in recent months it has backtracked on rules governing automobile emissions and deforestation.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.media:credit: Christophe Simon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Queuing for gas in southern France. Earlier this week, E.U. officials introduced a proposal that would walk back an effective ban on the production of gas- and diesel-powered cars by 2035.

item.title: Massachusetts Battery Start-Up to List on Stock Exchange
item.description: Factorial, the start-up, said the listing would provide money that would help it bring new solid-state batteries to market as soon as 2027.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.media:description: Siyu Huang is the chief executive of Factorial.

item.title: She Tracked Fish That Coastal Communities Depend On. Then She Was Fired From NOAA.
item.description: Ana Vaz monitored crucial fish stocks in the Southeast and the Gulf of Mexico until she lost her job at NOAA.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
